facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 144-145 of 1964 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCivil Appeals Nos. 144-145 of 1964. Appeals from the order dated November 16, 1960 of the Mysore High Court in

facts.text: Appeals from the order dated November 16, 1960 of the Mysore High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 3/1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals Nos. 144-145 of 1964. Appeals from the order dated November 16, 1960 of the Mysore High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 3/1959.

facts.text: Certificate granted by the High Court of Mysore under s. 66A of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: certificate granted by the High Court of Mysore under s. 66-A  2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, are directed against its judgment

facts.text: Question referred: Whether the assessee, Mohandas Sadhuram, can be granted registration under Section 26-A for 1953-54 on basis of deed dated 1-4-1952 and for 1954-55 on deed with supplementary deed 1-4-1953.

anchor.surface_text: answering the question referred to it in favour of the respondent-assessee. The question referred to is Whether the assessee, Mohandas Sadhuram, can be granted registration under Section 26-A of the Indian Income Tax Act on the basis of the partnership deed made on 1-4-1952

facts.text: Assessee is firm M s Shah Mohandas Sadhuram.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, M s Shah Mohandas Sadhuram, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a firm.

facts.text: Partnership Deed executed on April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed registration under s. 26-A of the Indian Income- Tax Act on the strength of a Partnership Deed executed on April 1, 1952.

facts.text: Four members were till this day members of a Joint Family, divided on 31-3-1952 into four shares of 1/4 each of assets and liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: Whereof the above four members were till this day members of a Joint Family, whereof yesterday that is on 31-3-1952 the said four members have become divided number only in interest but also by metes and bounds, each of the said members taking to his share one fourth  1/4  of the said joint family assets

facts.text: First and second members (Atmaram and Doulatram, majors) decided to constitute partnership admitting third and fourth members (minors) to benefits but not liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: and liabilities as detailed in the books of account as maintained by the firm known as Seth Mohandas Sadhuram and whereof we the first and second members have decided to companystitute all the said four members as a partnership admitting the third and fourth members thereof to the benefits of the said partnership but number to the liabilities thereunder.

facts.text: Firm to do business of Banking and Commerce, including Automobiles business under Vijaya Automobiles, Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The said firm is agreed to do business of Banking and Commerce  which term includes all that is usually and customarily is understood to be done thereunder  and also to deal in Automobiles business. The Automobiles business having been started by the said first and second members under the name and style of Vijaya Automobiles, Mysore,

facts.text: Capital contribution of each member equal, shown in personal capital ledger.

anchor.surface_text: It is agreed that the capital companytribution of each member will be equal and the accounts to be maintained to. indicate the said capital companytribution. will show what each member has so companytributed in the personal capital ledger account.

facts.text: Profits distributed pro rata capital after reserving for charity, losses shared similarly.

anchor.surface_text: It is further agreed that after debiting all working expenses inclusive of those referred to in para 6 supra. the profits of the firm less six pies per every rupee of profits which will be reserved for Charity Fund will be distributed pro rata according to the proportion of capital investment as detailed of each member.

facts.text: Share of profits for 3rd and 4th members paid to them via guardian.

anchor.surface_text: The share of profits for the 3rd and 4th member will be. paid to them. the said profits to be credited to theft accounts, and from there their maintenance charges and other expenses of necessities if any may be drawn by the said Guardian from the said accounts.

facts.text: Partnership duration one year from 1st April 1952 to 31st March 1953, continuable thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: It is agreed that the duration of this partnership will be for a period of one year, i.e. from 1st of April, 1952 to 31st March, 1953, and the members might agree to companytinue the said partnership even thereafter under these terms or on terms to be determined then.

facts.text: For assessment year 1953-54, Income Tax Officer rejected registration because minors made parties to contract by eldest brother, minor debited with loss.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1953-54. the Income Tax Officer rejected the application for registration on the ground that in the case of the assessee. the minors are made parties to a companytract by the eldest brother acting on their behalf. The minor has actually been debited with a share of loss.

facts.text: For 1954-55, ITO rejected also on ground of supplementary deed dated 1-4-1953 on 10 annas stamp paper extending partnership.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1954-55, he also rejected the application but added this further ground that a supplementary deed of partnership extending the life of the partnership beyond 1-4-1953 for a further period at the will of the partners is filed. This is on 10 annas stamp paper.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO orders for both years.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, on appeal, upheld the orders of the Income Tax Officer in respect of both the assessment years.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held assessee entitled to registration for both years, construing deed as admitting minors to benefits only, following Madras HC in Jakka Devayya.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Appellate Tribunal, following the decision of the Madras High Court in Jakka Devayya and Sons Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1  companystrued the deed as having admitted the minors only to the benefits of the partnership. It accordingly held that the assessee was entitled to be registered for both the years.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court at instance of Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income Tax, the Tribunal referred the question already set out above to the High Court.

facts.text: Mysore High Court answered in favor of assessee, following its judgment in ITR No. 2 of 1959 (Commissioner v. Ms Shah Jethaji Phulchand).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following its judgment in Income Tax Reference No. 2 of 1959, which is the subject- matter of appeal before us in The Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. M s Shah Jethaji Phulchand 2  answered the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant (Karkhanis) contends minors made full partners per clauses 4,7,8,10,11,12; guardian cannot contract for minor.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Karkhanis, the learned companynsel for the appellant companytends that on a proper companystruction of the deed it is clear that the minors have been made partners, and therefore the deed is number valid. He relies on clauses 4, 7, 8, 10, 11 and 12 of the Partnership deed,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds partnership deed confers only benefits on minors, not full partners; guardian can contract for benefits.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the partnership deed, reasonably companystrued, only companyfers benefits of partnership on the two minors and does number make them full partners. The guardian has agreed to certain clauses in order to effectuate the decision of the major members to companyfer the benefits of the said partnership to the minors.

facts.text: Firm entitled to registration under s. 26-A for both years.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we hold that the Income Tax authorities should number have declined to register the firm.

facts.text: Supplementary deed dated April 1, 1953 does not affect.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that the supplementary deed dated April 1, 1953, has number been included in the statement of the case, but it is companymon ground that numberhing turns on any of the clauses in the supplementary deed.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sikri, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J.

anchor.surface_text: The minor has actually been debited with a share of loss.

issues.text: Whether the assessee, Mohandas Sadhuram, can be granted registration under Section 26-A of the Indian Income Tax Act on the basis of the partnership deed made on 1-4-1952 for the assessment year 1953-54 and on the basis of the said deed read with the supplementary deed on 1-4-1953 for the assessment year 1954-55.

holdings.text: the partnership deed, reasonably construed, only confers benefits of partnership on the two minors and does not make them full partners. The guardian has agreed to certain clauses in order to effectuate the decision of the major members to confer the benefits of the said partnership to the minors.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the partnership deed, reasonably construed, only confers benefits of partnership on the two minors and does not make them full partners. The guardian has agreed to certain clauses in order to effectuate the decision of the major members to confer the benefits of the said partnership to the minors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recital admits minors to benefits only; clauses construed in that light consistent with s.30 Partnership Act; distinguishes Dwarkadas Khetan where minor full partner.

holdings.text: as long as a partnership deed does not make a minor full partner a partnership deed cannot be regarded as invalid on the ground that a guardian has purported to contract on behalf of a minor if the contract is for the purposes mentioned above.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from scheme of s.30 Partnership Act: minor not liable for losses, guardian can contribute capital, sever connection, accept terms to effectuate benefits without minor's knowledge.

holdings.text: Income Tax authorities should not have declined to register the firm.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we hold that the Income Tax authorities should not have declined to register the firm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed validly constitutes partnership admitting minors to benefits only, satisfying requirements for registration under s.26A.

holdings.text: the supplementary deed dated April 1, 1953, has not been included in the statement of the case, but it is common ground that nothing turns on any of the clauses in the supplementary deed.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that the supplementary deed dated April 1, 1953, has not been included in the statement of the case, but it is common ground that nothing turns on any of the clauses in the supplementary deed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties; does not affect validity for 1954-55.

holdings.text: the firm is entitled to be registered under s. 26-A of the Income Tax Act, and the answer to the question referred is in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the firm is entitled to be registered under s. 26-A of the Income Tax Act, and the answer to the question referred is in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court and Tribunal; deed construction supports registration for both years.

holdings.text: If it is one of the terms on which benefits of partnership are being conferred either the guardian must refuse to accept the benefits or he must accept this term [capital contribution].
holdings.reasoning_summary: Guardian power to accept terms necessary for benefits under s.30(4); avoidable by minor if not beneficial but valid unless avoided.

holdings.text: We can find no defect in this clause [duration]. The duration of a partnership has to be fixed between the major members, and the guardian on behalf of a minor may agree to accept the benefits of the partnership only if the duration is to the benefit of the minor.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Majors determine duration; guardian accepts if beneficial; future terms subject to law.

holdings.text: Clause 11 has reference to the manner of keeping accounts and a guardian is entitled to assent to the mode of keeping accounts.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 11 has reference to the manner of keeping accounts and a guardian is entitled to assent to the mode of keeping accounts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incidental to securing benefits; within guardian's competence.

precedents.citation: Jakka Devayya and Sons Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Jakka Devayya and Sons Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

precedents.case_name: Jakka Devayya & Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: construed the deed as having admitted the minors only to the benefits of the partnership

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. M s Shah Jethaji Phulchand 2

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. M s Shah Jethaji Phulchand 2

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. M/s Shah Jethaji Phulchand
precedents.cited_proposition: an instrument of partnership entered into between persons, some of whom are by law incompetent to contract, as might happen if one of them is a minor, is not necessarily null and void, and where the execution is for admitting minor to benefits of partnership, no question of invalidity arises

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan Co. 3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan Co. 3

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: income tax officer was only empowered to register a partnership which was specified in the instrument of partnership and it was not open to the Department to register a partnership different from that which was formed by the instrument; s. 30 of the Indian Partnership Act does not render a minor a competent and full partner, and any document which made a minor full partner could not be regarded as valid for registration
precedents.cited_holding: minor described as full partner entitled to profits and liable for losses including capital loss, to attend business, consent in writing, manage affairs, inspect books, vote

justification_sets.label: Admission of minor to benefits of partnership support
